choices.C: The downstream devices will appear in the root ADOM.
choices.D: The downstream devices must be added using the Add Device wizard.
choices.A: The downstream devices show as unauthorized in the Training ADOM.
choices.B: The downstream devices are automatically authorized.

discussion.content: C. The downstream devices will appear as unauthorized devices in the root ADOM

Selected Answer: A
correct answer is A, as the root fortigate is already added in Training ADOM.
All downstream fortigate in the sec fabric group will be added in unauthorized devices group in the same ADOM as the root.
C. The downstream devices will appear in the root ADOM.

questions.question_text:
An administrator created a new ADOM named Training for FortiGate devices only, and added the root FortiGate device of a Security Fabric group to the Training ADOM.
Given the administrator's actions, which statement correctly describes the expected result for the downstream devices in the Security Fabric?

choices.D: They support FTP, SCP, and SFTP.
choices.C: They put FortiManager in offline mode.
choices.B: They can be configured using the CLI and the GUI.
choices.A: They back up all devices and the FortiGuard database.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
B&D study guide page 73

B&D since this is schedule
A is not for schedule
B&D study

Selected Answer: BD
B and D are correct
FMG 7.4 Administrator Study Guide

questions.question_text: Which two statements about scheduled backups on FortiManager are true? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
B&C: 
B: Scheduled backups perform database integrity commands prior to a scheduled backup, and creates logs - page 261 in the Study Guide

C: Not following the correct upgrade patch can cause inconsistencies in the database. Page 260 in the study guide.

Selected Answer: BC
B,C
Study guide

B: it's OK from study guide p261: FortiManager automatically runs database
integrity commands prior to a schedule backup and creates logs
C: it' OK from study guide p260: Always follow the correct upgrade path. If you don’t, it may cause inconsistencies in the databas
D: it's wrong. from study guide p261: It is recommended that you perform
a backup before executing database integrity commands.

Selected Answer: BC
For sure 100%
A&E are incorrect
B is correct

Have a doubt about C&D, but will go for C correct as it s recommended to perform a Backup before launching database integrity check, which is supposed to fix issues

questions.question_text: Which two statements about the integrity of databases on FortiManager are correct? (Choose two.)

choices.E: The diagnose cdb check adom-integrity command can correct issues related to looked devices.
choices.B: Scheduled backups run database integrity commands automatically.
choices.C: Not following the correct upgrade path may cause inconsistencies in the databases.
choices.D: You should fix all database integrity issues before performing a backup.
choices.A: The diagnose dvm check-integrity command attempts to fix a corrupted file system.

questions.question_text: If both FortiManager and FortiGate are behind NAT devices, what are the two expected results? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
A&D are correct.
study guide

Selected Answer: AD
A&D are correct answers

B is incorrect. Fortigate can announce itself to FMG in the case FMG Nated IP address is configured under central management
C is incorrect, as in this scenario only Fortigate can try to reestablish the FGFM tunnel when it s torn down.

FYI D is correct because of "by default". During discovery process, FMG Nated IP address is set on FGT only if in the FMG admin setting Nated ip address has been specify like mgmt address.

FMG Administrator Study Guide

B&D 
Fortimanager can discover FortiGate through a NATed FortiGate IP address. If a FortiManager NATed IP address is configured on FortiGate, then FortiGate can announce itself to FortiManager. FortiManager will not attempt to re-establish the FGFM tunnel to the FortiGate NATed IP address, if the FGFM tunnel is interrupted.
Just like it was in the NATed FortiManager scenario, the FortiManager NATed IP address in this scenario is not configured under FortiGate central management configuration.
A and D

choices.B: FortiGate can announce itself to FortiManager only if the FortiManager non-NATed IP address is configured on FortiGate under central management.
choices.C: If the FGFM tunnel is torn down, FortiManager will try to re-establish the FGFM tunnel.
choices.D: During discovery, the FortiManager NATed IP address is not set by default on FortiGate.
choices.A: FortiGate is discovered by FortiManager through the FortiGate NATed IP address.

choices.B: Configuration changes have been installed on FortiGate, which means the FortiGate configuration has been changed.
choices.A: The latest revision history for the managed FortiGate does not match the device-level database.
choices.D: The latest revision history for the managed FortiGate does match the FortiGate running configuration.
choices.C: Configuration changes directly made on FortiGate have been automatically updated to the device-level database.

discussion.content:
A&D are correct.

– conf: in sync – This is the sync status which shows that the latest revision history is in sync with Fortigate’s configuration.
- There is a new modification on FortiManager device level DB (dev-db: modified) which wasn’t installed to FortiGate (cond: pending)

Selected Answer: AD
pag 131 fortimanager study guide

comments.content: you're right, after reading it again I realized that... A&D are correct!

No 
dev-db: modified, means modifications have been done on device level directly on Fortimanager, but not yet installed on managed device.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
A,B
dev-db: modified - This status indicates that the device-level database in FortiManager has unsynchronized changes, meaning that the latest revision history stored in FortiManager does not match the configuration that was installed on the FortiGate.
conf: in sync - Since configuration changes have been installed successfully on the FortiGate from FortiManager, this status would show as "in sync." This status indicates that FortiGate’s running configuration now aligns with the last installed configuration, even if the device-level database in FortiManager does not match the latest revision history.^
cond: pending - FortiManager knows the change was made directly on FortiGate

Selected Answer: AD
Answer A and D

B is false cause dev-db is modified so configurations changes have not been installed
C is false cause dm is retrieved and not auto-updated

A&D are correct

Selected Answer: AD
Correct answer is A & D

Selected Answer: AD
Answer is A & D

Selected Answer: AB
dm: retrieved is not dm: autoupdated which makes option C invalid
A&D are correct
